entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys
entry.content:
In this series:

  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys (this blog post)

API keys are required when called SAP Build Process Automation keys, but it can be confusing to know you need to provide, what different keys will return, and how to set it all up.

When do you need an API key?

Each environment lets you assign permissions to users for that environment. To do this, in the environment, click on Share.

Then you will be able to assign to a user specific authorizations. @Alex-Fortin (who is brilliant) has a wonderful blog about "shared" environments and assigning authorizations, including a table of what each authorization enables.

Different authorizations will allow you different API calls, but let's use the Workflow API as an example. If you have the Monitor authorization than you will be able to run the Workflow API for this environment.

To make it more complicated, you can also have the ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection (from the SAP BTP cockpit) and then you can run this API for any environment, without needing authorizations for any of the environments. 

And ll of this works WITHOUT ANY API KEY if you are authenticated using user token exchange. But if you are using client credentials and are authenticated simply as the service, then you need an API key. 

 

How to create an API key?

Go to the SAP Build Control Tower and click Others > API Keys. 

Then just create a new API key.

Then you set the following:

  • Name/Description
  • Scopes, that is, what authorizations assigned to the key. There is information on what each scope means 
  • Environments, that is, for which environments the key will work. You can specify one or more environments, or you can give the key access to all environments, including future ones. 

The scopes are explained in this documentation page. For reading workflow instances, you need trigger_read and environment_read scopes.

When you are finished, the key is displayed. You have one chance to copy it, and then you can no longer retrieve it from SAP Build.

Note that there is also a UI for creating API keys in each environment. The UI is the same except that that environment is automatically selected and you cannot select a different one.

 

What does API return based on the key?

If the API key is required, you must provide it as an HTTP header with the name api-key.

Note that the key used to be irpa-api-key, or something like that. I went crazy wondering why my API calls were not working, until something told me that the key name had apparently changed. üòæ

The following is a summary of what happens given the example of calling the GET call of the Workflow API's workflow-instances, depending on:

  • How you authenticate
  • What role the user has (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether the user has the Monitor authorization for the given environment (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether an API key is sent that is valid and has the correct scopes for the given API
ProcessAutomationAdmin Role CollectionAPI KeyMonitor AuthorizationAuthenticationDoes API return values?
‚úÖNANAUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚úÖUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚ùåUser Token Exchange ‚ùå
 NA ‚ùåNA Client Credentials ‚ùå 
 NA‚úÖNA Client Credentials ‚úÖ

As an example, in this call:

  • I am authenticated using client credentials.
  • A URL parameter indicates to return only workflow instances from the salesgroup environment.
  • I supplied an API key for the salesgroup environment with trigger_read and environment_read  scopes  

And now I can see the running instances for that environment.

In upcoming blogs, we'll look at specific APIs, what they return/do and how to use them.

P.S.: Apologies for taking so long on this Part II üòΩ

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
You are saying you have an array of IDs in the accountTechnicalId field, and you want your Get to return all items whose account.id field is in that list?

In general, I would not use that GetRecordCollection feature but try to construct a $filter that looks something like this:

GET /service/Products?$filter=Name in ('Milk', 'Cheese', 'Donut')

I wrote this about creating $filter in Build Apps, but that was before Build Apps supported Actions, which I think would be the better way: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/odata-filtering-in-sap-build-apps-could-this-work-for-you/ba-p/13566627

Let me know exactly what you need and I will try to see how this can be done.

entry.title: Re: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
Great blog üò∏

In my set up I had to add extensibility_developer role, but above it says joule_extensibility. Is my set up different?

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
I still would rework the data connection, and I think it more elegant to do this with OData IN $filter, but if you want to do the filtering in the Get Record Collection flow function, what about this.

Create a filter page variable like this.

Set the page variable with the fields you want. Here I hard-code the values but you could use a MAP function to parse your IDs. The property field is a list but you just put a single string, the name of the field on which to filter.

And then in the Get Record Collection filter, you set to formula and do something like this:

Would this work?

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
I made a little app/UI where I return values from our OData service for our CodeJam.

I'm able to create a list of strings and then use that to filter the list of emails.

 

I used a formula like this:

MAP(pageVars.strings,{type: "startswith", property: ["customer"], value: item.mystring})

Of course you will get the filter values from your app variable

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data set¬†using more than one value of this prope
entry.content: I still do not understand why my suggestion would not work for you. Your IDs are stored in an App variable instead of my page variable.

entry.title: üáÆüáπ Joule Studio: Create Joule Skills and Agents Without Coding (Milan, Italy)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio ‚Äì such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

Currently, much of the session is based on the TechEd hands-on tutorials for AI163.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 3, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Milan, Italy (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: Via Bisceglie, 66, 20152 ‚Äì Impresoft Offices, Milan, Italy

  • The event is kindly being hosted by Syscons ‚Äì THANK YOU!
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocate @Dan_Wroblewski.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 25 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.

entry.title: Re: how to setup resource group in the Joule Agent Builder
entry.content:
Yes, the way adding Documents to Joule Agent recently changed.

The idea now is that an admin will enable different Document collections in the Control Tower, and make them available to developers. It seems soon they will also allow admins to specify the environments that each document collection can be used in.

Then the developers will be able to add documents to their agents without having to do the work of setting them up. 

  • According to documentation, you must have AI Core and Object Store (I assume in the future you can have other document repositories): https://help.sap.com/docs/Joule_Studio/45f9d2b8914b4f0ba731570ff9a85313/626498be11064953810a852535900ca7.html?locale=en-US
  • You can set up Document Grounding in AI Core to use SharePoint, and there were TechEd sessions on how to do that. But these pipelines as far as I know cannot currently be used in Joule Agents.

entry.title: Re: how to setup resource group in the Joule Agent Builder
entry.content:
You need the following properties:

  • AI Core destination
    • sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-ai-core = true
  • Object Store destination
    • sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store = true

entry.title: üá©üá™ SAP Build: Create Event-Based Processes (Heidelberg, Germany)
entry.content:
This SAP Build low-code/no-code SAP CodeJam focuses on giving you hands-on experience for building event-triggered processes with SAP Build Process Automation, and how to work with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh to send those events to your processes.

You will build an event-based scenario that lets users create S/4HANA business partners, setting off a process where:

  1. An employee approves the creation of a site access badge.
  2. A second employee, determined based on the details of the business partner, may also need to approve the badge.
  3. The process calls an external, 3rd-party badge system and waits to be called back.
  4. A user creates the badge and the badge system calls back the process instance.
  5. A notification with the badge ID is sent.

The scenario is built in 2 halves:

  • SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh: You will get to know all about events, CloudEvents, events in the SAP landscape, the process for publishing and subscribing to events, and your way around SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Then you will create a REST Delivery Point in advanced event mesh to forward events to your SAP Build on your SAP BTP trial account.
  • SAP Build Process Automation: You will create a process from scratch to handle the issuance of site access badges. You will learn the basics of SAP Build Process Automation (projects, triggers, conditions, creating instances, monitoring, and the Inbox), and also use some of the more recent or advanced features (event triggers, form events, waiting for a API callback).

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have.
  • Complete these prerequisites BEFORE you come: 
    • Introduction to the CodeJam
    • Prerequisites

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 9, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Heidelberg, Germany (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: sovanta AG, Mittermaierstra√üe 31, 69115 Heidelberg, Germany

  • The event is kindly being hosted by sovanta AG ‚Äì THANK YOU!
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocate @Dan_Wroblewski.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 25 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance.

entry.title: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
Several people have reached out to me this week to describe the new way you set up document grounding with Joule Studio. So here goes.

What is Document Grounding

Many of you may know about Document Grounding, but for those who don't here's a very brief explanation.

  1. The basic way we use AI is to send a prompt to an LLM (a set of "indexed" information).
  2. If we want the LLM to take into account additional information it may not have, we can provide "context" (though the amount of "context" you are allowed to send may be constrained).

One of those pieces of context may come from a set of documents (e.g., housed in SharePoint or in the SAP BTP Object Store service). In order to use those documents as context we must perform Document Grounding, which takes the documents, "chunks" them into small pieces, and then "embeds" them so they can be used as context in our AI requests.

In Joule Studio, when we create agents, we essentially specify an LLM to handle specific types of prompts, and then provide context and instructions for what we want the agent to do.

The "Old" Way in Joule Studio

The old way we performed Document Grounding in Joule Studio was to go into AI Core and create a resource group, connect that resource group to a content store (e.g., the place we store the documents), and have AI Core chunk and embed the documents so we could use the content within an agent or for use when sending a prompt to AI Core. Joule Studio would be configured to connect with a specific AI Core, and the developer of an agent would type in the name of a resource group in AI Core to use with their agent.

Here we can see in the SAP AI Launchpad that we are connected to the "dbw" resource, and we have created a "pipeline" with documents.

If we click inside, we can see that this pipeline has 4 documents, each chunked and embedded. 

But doing this required going into the SAP AI Launchpad, creating Generic Secrets by encoding credentials in Base64, and several more steps in tools we may not be familiar with.

Joule Studio still makes use of the same mechanism in AI Core, but now takes care of creating all the artifacts behind the scene (and enables some new capabilities).  

 

1. Prerequisites

You need an instance of SAP AI Core and an S3-compatible document store such as the Object Store service in BTP. I won't go into setting these up, but you can find out more information here:

  • AI Core
  • Object Store

If you need more information, leave a comment.

Note you can define many instances of AI Core and Object Store to be used with Joule Studio.

 

2. Destinations

You need to set up destinations to AI Core and Object Store on both your SAP Build tenant and your Joule tenant. 

AI Core Destination

Get the service key of your AI Core instance, and create a destination as shown below.

Append /oauth/token to the url value of the service key and use this for the destination's Token Service URL.

Add the additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-ai-core and set it to true. This makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

Object Store Destination

Similarly, get the service key for the object store service instance and set the following destination fields with the corresponding service field value:

Destination FieldService Key Field
URLaccess_key_id
Client IDhost (add https://)
Client Secretsecret_access_key
Token Service URLhost (add https://)

Add the following additional properties:

Additional PropertyValue
regionregion value from service key
bucketbucket value from service key
usernameusername value from service key
typeS3
sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store
true

The additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

3. Set Up in Control Tower

In the Control Tower, the SAP Build admin will decide:

  • From which object stores to create Document Grounding.
  • In which AI Core instances to create these Document Grounding pipelines.

The Control Tower now has a Joule section, including a Document Grounding tile so the admin can create Document Grounding and make it available to Joule Studio developers.

Click the Document Grounding tile. You can now create sets of Document Grounding.

Note that while in the SAP AI Launchpad you could create different pipelines with different sets of documents in the same resource group, here each object store will create a separate resource group.

Click Add.

Give the resource group a name.

Select the AI Core instance in which to create the resource group.

And finally select the object store whose documents you want to ground.

Click Add.

The status of the resource group will be Pending. 

After about a minute (depending on the size of the documents), the status will change to Completed.

(Early on, I occasionally got Error messages, or Pending simply remained for a long time, and sometimes they would alternate between those messages. In such cases, make sure the destinations are configured properly and make sure the documents in the Object Store are not corrupted.)

If you now look in SAP AI Launchpad, and go to SAP AI Core Administration > Resource Groups, you will see a new resource group whose name is the name you specified (without spaces) with a Unix timestamp appended.

Though the resource group should immediately appear on the Resource Groups page, it may take a few extra minutes for the resource group to appear on the Workspaces page. 

Once it does, you can select it and see the pipeline and Document Grounding inside the resource group. 

 

4. Add Document Grounding to Your Agent 

Now that the admin has set up a resource group and triggered the document grounding for a set of documents, developers of Joule Studio agents can use them in their agents.

Inside an agent, the developer can specify tools, including documents. Select Add Tools > Documents.

This opens a dialogue to specify which resource group created by the admin to use. Specify a name for the documents (as seen in the agent) and a description to help the agent know when to use them.

Then select from among the resource groups created by the admin.

Advantages

The advantages of this method are:

  • Admins and developers no longer have to work in AI Launchpad, including creating Generic Secrets and dealing with Base64 encoding of credentials.
  • Admins decide what document grounding gets used in Joule Studio agents.
    • From the look of the UI, admins will eventually be able to assign a resource group to a specific environment, giving admins even more control
  • Developers have a predefined set of  resource groups to choose from, using a dropdown list.
  • More than one AI Core instance and more than one Object Store instance can be used to define document grounding for a Joule Studio.

Note that this method creates a single document grounding pipeline in each resource group it creates; using AI Launchpad, you can create multiple pipelines in a single resource group.

There may be more advantages and limitations. Please add a comment with your opinion about this feature, or anything I missed.

entry.title: Improve Build Apps UIs to Allow Keyboard Click / Control Focus
entry.content:
I was doing this great tutorial by my colleagues @Rekha_DR and @shrinivasan_neelamegam about creating a chatbot using Build Apps and AI Core, a topic they delivered in the SAP TechEd developer keynote in 2024: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2024-developer-keynote/blob/main/topics/DEV100A-build-chatbot-apps-aicore/README.md

It worked perfectly. 

The tutorial let you create a chatbot where you typed a prompt, got an answer, and then could send a new prompt, like a regular chatbot. (By the way, one of the clever designs of theirs was that the context of the conversation was always sent back to the AI Core with every subsequent prompt.)

I thought what would make the app even more helpful would be:

  • To be able to press Enter after typing in each prompt.
  • To place the cursor automatically in the prompt input box so the user could just start typing the next prompt.

 

Allow Enter Instead of Button Click

To do this, you first want to create a custom event for the logic that you want connected to the button click / Enter press.

Drag a Receive Event flow function onto the canvas.

Set the Event Source to Fired from "Trigger Event", and give the event a name, like SendChat.

Attach your logic (in this case the calls to AI Core) to the event.

Now all that's left is to trigger this event when the user clicks the button, or presses Enter. 

For the button click, select the button click, drag a Trigger Event flow function, and connect it to your Component Tap event for the button.

Configure the Trigger Event flow function by selecting your new event to be triggered.

To enable the logic to be triggered by pressing Enter, highlight your input box, and create the following logic on the input box's onKeyPress event.

To the onKeyPress event, add an If Condition flow function with the following formula:

outputs["Receive event"].eventValue == "Enter"

And then to the top output add a Trigger Event, configured the same as for the button click logic above.

 

Place Cursor in Input Box

Every time I send a prompt, I want the cursor to return to the input box so I can type in the next prompt.

Install the Focus Input flow function from the Marketplace.

After the logic for sending the prompt and receiving the answer from AI Core, add this flow function and specify the input box.

üòΩ

entry.title: Re: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
@Cocquerel The short answer is this is a function of AI Core, and I am not an expert on the intricacies of how AI Core creates a pipeline and handles the data from the document. ARe you saying you want the LLM to provide an answer to a prompt, but then a type of footnote linking to the document it took the answer from?

 @noravonthenen maybe you know how this could be done?

entry.title: Re: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content: @chen_zhao02 Thanks for pointing out. Fixed.

entry.title: Re: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
@Cocquerel Firstly, the page in discovery center is confusing to me since it seems to say a Record costs 0.005 of an AI Unit, and an AI Unit costs 7 euros, but then it says cost of a record is 7 euros (I would have thought it was 3.5 cents in euros).

It looks like the official page for AI pricing is here: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/pricing.html

On this page it talks a little bit more about pricing and records: https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/metering-and-pricing?locale=en-US

It's not clear to me if I upload a document that is 1KB would I still pay for 1 record, or whether 45MB can count for several documents.

 I am not an expert on pricing, sorry.

entry.title: Re: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content: @Cocquerel As far as I know, at the moment, you cannot create a pipeline in AI Core and then use it in Joule Studio. But I am told they are working on that.

entry.title: üá®üá≠ Joule Studio: Create Joule Skills and Agents Without Coding (Risch-Rotkreuz, Switzerland)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio ‚Äì such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

Currently, much of the session is based on the TechEd hands-on tutorials for AI163.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, March 17, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Risch-Rotkeuz, Switzerland (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.
